[start of motion plan]
The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
To estimate the forces and torques required to accomplish give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck, we must consider the following:
- Object Properties: {DESCRIPTION: The neck is human tissue, composed of muscle and bone. It's relatively flexible and sensitive to pressure. The mass of the neck is estimated to be around 3 kg. The skin has a relatively high coefficient of friction.}
- Environmental Factors: {DESCRIPTION: Gravity acts on the neck. The person is assumed to be relatively still but will react to discomfort, so the motion must be smooth and gentle.}
- The relevant object is {DESCRIPTION: human neck} has mass {3} kg and, with the robot gripper, has a static friction coefficient of {0.6}.
- The surface of interaction is {DESCRIPTION: skin} has a static friction coefficient of {0.6} with the object.
- Contact Types: {DESCRIPTION: Surface contact with the gripper for grasping and massaging.}
- Motion Type: {DESCRIPTION: Gentle grasping followed by a combination of linear (sliding) and rotational (kneading) motions.}
- Contact Considerations: {DESCRIPTION: The robot needs to maintain a consistent grasp on the neck to apply the massage. Force feedback is crucial to avoid excessive pressure.}
- Motion along axes: {DESCRIPTION: The robot exerts motion in a combination fashion along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes. Linear motions will be small and slow; the rotational motion will emulate kneading.}
- Task duration: {DESCRIPTION: I estimate the task duration to be approximately 20 seconds based on the motion, forces, and torques applied.}.

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: {DESCRIPTION: Mass of the neck ~ 3 kg, friction coefficient ~ 0.6, desired massage force ~ 5N.}
- Relevant equations: {DESCRIPTION: Frictional force = coefficient of friction * normal force.}
- Relevant assumptions: {DESCRIPTION: The neck is assumed to be roughly cylindrical, and the person is assumed to tolerate a moderate grasping force without discomfort.}
- Computations: {DESCRIPTION: Frictional force = 0.6 * 5 = 3N. This is the estimated force to prevent slippage during the massage.}
- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass {3} kg and static friction coefficient of {0.6} along the surface: {DESCRIPTION:  The force required to overcome friction and achieve the task of massage is estimated based on the friction between the gripper and the neck surface.}

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis: To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: the need to gently knead the neck by moving the end effector slightly along the X axis}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: positive} force along the X-axis with magnitude {0.5} N on the object in the image.
Linear Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: the need to maintain the grip on the neck and gently move the end effector}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: no} force along the Y-axis with magnitude {0.0} N on the object in the image.
Linear Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: the need to maintain grip on the neck with a slight force along Z axis while avoiding over-compression of the neck}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: negative} force along the Z-axis with magnitude {3.0} N on the object in the image.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: the need to apply a gentle kneading motion with small oscillations of the end effector}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: angular counterclockwise} torque about the X-axis with magnitude {0.2} N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: there is no need to tilt the head along Y axis}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: angular no} torque about the Y-axis with magnitude {0.0} N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon {DESCRIPTION: the need to gently rotate along the Z axis}, the robot must exert {CHOICE: angular clockwise} torque about the Z-axis with magnitude {0.1} N-m on the object in the image.
Grasping force: {DESCRIPTION: A gentle grasp is required to manipulate the neck. Too much force can cause discomfort or injury.}. Thus {3} to {5} N .

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "Human neck, approx. 3kg, tissue, friction 0.6"
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Gentle grasp and massage with small linear and rotational movements"
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [0.5, 0.0, -3.0, 0.2, 0.0, -0.1]
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 4.0
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 20.0
```

[end of motion plan]

- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist

- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
